Fungal Infection.description: Fungal infections are caused by fungi that invade the skin, nails, or other body parts. Common types include athlete's foot, ringworm, yeast infections, and nail fungus.
symptoms: Itching and redness of affected area
White patches on skin or mouth
causes: Contact with infected persons or surfaces
treatment: Oral antifungal medications for severe cases
Keep affected areas clean and dry
Use antifungal powders in shoes and socks
Fungal Infection.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if the infection spreads, doesn't improve with OTC treatment within 2 weeks, or if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system.

Allergy.description: Allergies occur when the immune system overreacts to harmless substances like pollen, dust, pet dander, or certain foods, causing symptoms ranging from mild to severe.
symptoms: Swelling of lips, tongue, or throat
causes: Pollen from trees, grass, or weeds
Allergy.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate medical care for severe reactions (anaphylaxis) with difficulty breathing, swelling of throat, or rapid heartbeat. See a doctor if allergies significantly affect quality of life.

GERD.description: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic digestive condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the esophagus, causing irritation and discomfort.
risk_factors: Eating large meals or late at night
GERD.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have heartburn more than twice a week, difficulty swallowing, persistent nausea or vomiting, or weight loss due to difficulty eating.

Chronic Cholestasis.description: Chronic cholestasis is a condition where bile flow from the liver is reduced or blocked, leading to bile buildup and liver damage over time.
Chronic Cholestasis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor immediately if you develop jaundice, severe itching, or dark urine. Regular monitoring is essential for chronic conditions.

Drug Reaction.description: An adverse drug reaction is an unwanted or harmful response to a medication. Reactions can range from mild skin rashes to severe life-threatening conditions.
treatment: Supportive care in hospital if severe
Drug Reaction.when_to_see_doctor: Seek emergency care immediately for difficulty breathing, swelling of face or throat, rapid heartbeat, or severe skin reactions. Report all drug reactions to your doctor.

Peptic Ulcer Disease.description: Peptic ulcer disease involves open sores that develop on the inside lining of the stomach (gastric ulcers) or the upper portion of the small intestine (duodenal ulcers).
symptoms: Pain that improves with eating (duodenal) or worsens (gastric)
treatment: Antibiotics to kill H. pylori (if present)
Peptic Ulcer Disease.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care if you have sharp, sudden stomach pain, bloody or black stools, or vomiting blood. See a doctor if symptoms persist despite treatment.

AIDS.description: AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is the most advanced stage of HIV infection, characterized by severe immune system damage, leaving the body vulnerable to opportunistic infections.
symptoms: Diarrhea lasting more than a week
causes: Transmitted through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, breast milk
treatment: Regular monitoring of CD4 count and viral load
AIDS.when_to_see_doctor: Get tested if you've had potential exposure to HIV. If diagnosed with HIV, regular medical care is essential. Seek immediate care for signs of opportunistic infections.

Diabetes.description: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic condition where the body cannot properly process blood glucose (sugar), leading to high blood sugar levels that can cause serious health complications.
causes: Type 1: Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells
Type 2: Insulin resistance and inadequate insulin production
Diabetes.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have symptoms of diabetes. Seek emergency care for signs of diabetic ketoacidosis (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion) or severely low blood sugar.

Gastroenteritis.description: Gastroenteritis, commonly called stomach flu, is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines usually caused by viral or bacterial infection, leading to diarrhea and vomiting.
risk_factors: Travel to areas with poor sanitation
treatment: Gradual return to normal diet (BRAT diet)
Gastroenteritis.when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical care if you can't keep liquids down for 24 hours, have bloody vomit or stools, fever above 104°F (40°C), signs of dehydration, or symptoms lasting more than a few days.

Bronchial Asthma.description: Bronchial asthma is a chronic respiratory condition where airways become inflamed, narrow, and produce excess mucus, causing difficulty breathing, wheezing, and coughing.
symptoms: Coughing, especially at night or early morning
Difficulty sleeping due to breathing problems
Symptoms worsen with exercise or cold air
causes: Allergic reactions (pollen, dust mites, pet dander)
risk_factors: Family history of asthma or allergies
Smoking or exposure to secondhand smoke
Bronchial Asthma.when_to_see_doctor: Seek emergency care if you have severe shortness of breath, can't speak due to breathing difficulty, or symptoms don't improve with quick-relief inhaler. Regular follow-up is essential for asthma management.

Hypertension.description: Hypertension (high blood pressure) is a chronic condition where blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated, increasing risk of heart disease, stroke, and other complications.
causes: Secondary hypertension: Kidney disease, thyroid problems, medications, sleep apnea
treatment: DASH diet (low sodium, rich in fruits and vegetables)
Hypertension.when_to_see_doctor: Have blood pressure checked regularly. Seek immediate care if blood pressure is extremely high (180/120 or higher) or if you have symptoms like chest pain, difficulty breathing, or vision changes.

Migraine.description: Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.
symptoms: Severe throbbing or pulsing headache (often one-sided)
treatment: Pain relievers (ibuprofen, acetaminophen) for mild migraines
Triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan) for moderate to severe
Migraine.when_to_see_doctor: Seek emergency care for sudden, severe headache (thunderclap headache), headache with fever, stiff neck, confusion, seizures, or double vision. See a doctor if migraines are frequent or don't respond to treatment.

Cervical Spondylosis.description: Cervical spondylosis is age-related wear and tear affecting the spinal disks in the neck, causing pain, stiffness, and sometimes nerve compression.
symptoms: Numbness or tingling in arms, hands, or fingers
causes: Dehydration and shrinkage of spinal discs
treatment: Surgery in severe cases with nerve compression
Cervical Spondylosis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have severe or worsening neck pain, numbness or weakness in arms or legs, or loss of bladder or bowel control (emergency).

Paralysis (Brain Hemorrhage).description: Brain hemorrhage (hemorrhagic stroke) occurs when blood vessels in the brain rupture, causing bleeding that damages brain tissue and can lead to paralysis and other serious complications.
symptoms: Weakness or numbness on one side of body
treatment: Emergency medical care - TIME IS CRITICAL
Surgery to stop bleeding or remove blood clot
Paralysis (Brain Hemorrhage).when_to_see_doctor: CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES IMMEDIATELY if you observe signs of stroke. Remember FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency.

Jaundice.description: Jaundice is a condition characterized by yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels, often indicating liver problems, bile duct obstruction, or blood disorders.
symptoms: Yellow discoloration of skin and eyes
causes: Hemolytic anemia (excessive breakdown of red blood cells)
treatment: Liver transplant for severe liver disease
Jaundice.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor promptly if you notice yellowing of skin or eyes. Seek immediate care if accompanied by severe abdominal pain, fever, or mental confusion.

Malaria.description: Malaria is a life-threatening mosquito-borne disease caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted through the bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
causes: Can also spread through blood transfusion or shared needles
risk_factors: Living in or traveling to endemic areas (Africa, South Asia, South America)
Malaria.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate medical attention if you develop fever after traveling to a malaria-endemic area. Malaria can become life-threatening within hours if not treated.

Chicken Pox.description: Chickenpox (varicella) is a highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy, blister-like rash. It's most common in children but can be more severe in adults.
symptoms: Itchy rash that turns into fluid-filled blisters
Rash appears in waves over several days
causes: Spread through direct contact with rash
Airborne transmission through coughing or sneezing
treatment: Acetaminophen for fever (NOT aspirin in children)
Keep nails short to prevent scratching
Chicken Pox.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if rash spreads to eyes, you have difficulty breathing, fever over 102°F (39°C), signs of skin infection (redness, warmth, pus), or if you're pregnant, immunocompromised, or an adult.

Dengue.description: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection common in tropical regions, causing flu-like symptoms that can progress to severe, potentially life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever.
causes: Transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes (especially A. aegypti)
Mosquitoes bite during day, especially early morning and evening
risk_factors: Living in or traveling to tropical/subtropical areas
Previous dengue infection (increases risk of severe dengue)
Dengue.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate medical care if you have severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, bleeding, difficulty breathing, or fatigue. Warning signs typically appear as fever subsides.

Typhoid.description: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, spread through contaminated food and water, common in areas with poor sanitation.
causes: Spread through contaminated food and water
risk_factors: Travel to endemic areas (South Asia, Africa, South America)
Eating food prepared by infected handlers
Typhoid.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you develop fever after traveling to endemic areas. Seek immediate care for severe abdominal pain (possible intestinal perforation), confusion, or inability to eat or drink.

Hepatitis A.description: Hepatitis A is a highly contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus, typically spread through contaminated food or water or close contact with an infected person.
risk_factors: Travel to areas with high hepatitis A rates
Living with someone who has hepatitis A
Men who have sex with men
treatment: No specific treatment - body clears virus on its own
Hepatitis A.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you develop symptoms of hepatitis A, especially jaundice. Seek immediate care if you have severe abdominal pain or signs of liver failure.

Hepatitis B.description: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease, transmitted through blood and body fluids.
causes: Spread through blood, semen, and other body fluids
treatment: Acute: Usually resolves on its own with rest and fluids
Hepatitis B.when_to_see_doctor: Get tested if you're at risk or have symptoms. Regular monitoring is essential for chronic hepatitis B. Seek immediate care for severe abdominal pain or signs of liver failure.

Hepatitis C.description: Hepatitis C is a viral infection that causes liver inflammation and damage, primarily spread through contact with infected blood. Many people don't know they're infected until liver damage appears.
risk_factors: Born to mother with hepatitis C
treatment: Vaccination for hepatitis A and B
Hepatitis C.when_to_see_doctor: Get tested if you have risk factors. Regular monitoring is essential during and after treatment. Seek care for signs of liver disease progression.

Hepatitis D.description: Hepatitis D (delta hepatitis) is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis D virus, which only occurs in people already infected with hepatitis B.
causes: Hepatitis D virus (requires hepatitis B to replicate)
Spread through blood and body fluids
Can occur as coinfection or superinfection
treatment: Liver transplant for end-stage liver disease
Hepatitis D.when_to_see_doctor: If you have hepatitis B, get tested for hepatitis D. Seek immediate care for signs of liver failure or severe symptoms.

Hepatitis E.description: Hepatitis E is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis E virus, typically spread through contaminated drinking water, common in areas with poor sanitation.
Hepatitis E.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you develop symptoms after travel to endemic areas. Pregnant women should seek immediate care as hepatitis E can be serious during pregnancy.

Alcoholic Hepatitis.description: Alcoholic hepatitis is inflammation of the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption, ranging from mild to severe life-threatening disease.
Alcoholic Hepatitis.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care if you have severe abdominal pain, vomiting blood, or confusion. See a doctor for any symptoms of liver disease if you drink alcohol regularly.

Tuberculosis.description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other organs. It spreads through airborne droplets when infected people cough or sneeze.
treatment: Common drugs: isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, pyrazinamide
Tuberculosis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have a persistent cough, unexplained weight loss, or night sweats. Get tested if you've been exposed to someone with TB or have risk factors.

Common Cold.description: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract affecting the nose and throat. While usually harmless, symptoms can be uncomfortable for 7-10 days.
treatment: Honey for cough (adults and children over 1)
Common Cold.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if symptoms last more than 10 days, you have high fever, severe sore throat, or symptoms that worsen after initial improvement. Seek care for infants with cold symptoms.

Pneumonia.description: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing.
symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
causes: Aspiration of food, drink, or vomit
Pneumonia.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care for difficulty breathing, chest pain, persistent fever over 102°F (39°C), or confusion. High-risk individuals should see a doctor at first symptoms.

Hemorrhoids (Piles).description: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus that can cause pain, itching, and bleeding, especially during bowel movements.
symptoms: Itching or irritation in anal region
causes: Sitting for long periods on toilet
Hemorrhoids (Piles).when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have rectal bleeding (to rule out other conditions), severe pain, or hemorrhoids that don't improve with home treatment.

Heart Attack.description: A heart attack (myocardial infarction) occurs when blood flow to part of the heart muscle is blocked, usually by a blood clot, causing tissue damage. It's a medical emergency.
symptoms: Chest pain or pressure (may spread to arm, jaw, back)
Heart Attack.when_to_see_doctor: CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES (911) IMMEDIATELY if you suspect a heart attack. Do not drive yourself to the hospital. Every minute matters.

Varicose Veins.description: Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted veins that commonly appear in the legs and feet, caused by weakened or damaged valves in the veins.
symptoms: Veins that appear twisted and bulging
Aching or heavy feeling in legs
Worsened pain after sitting or standing for long time
risk_factors: Standing or sitting for long periods
Varicose Veins.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if self-care measures don't help, you're concerned about appearance, or you develop skin changes, ulcers, or significant pain.

Hypothyroidism.description: Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to slowed metabolism and various symptoms.
treatment: Regular blood tests to monitor levels
Hypothyroidism.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have symptoms of hypothyroidism, especially fatigue and unexplained weight gain. Regular follow-up is essential once on treatment.

Hyperthyroidism.description: Hyperthyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone, speeding up metabolism and causing various symptoms.
Hyperthyroidism.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have rapid heartbeat, unexplained weight loss, or other symptoms. Seek immediate care for thyroid storm (fever, rapid heartbeat, confusion).

Urinary Tract Infection.description: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of the urinary system — kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. Most infections involve the lower urinary tract.
symptoms: Passing frequent, small amounts of urine
Urinary Tract Infection.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have UTI symptoms, especially if accompanied by fever, back pain, nausea, or vomiting (signs of kidney infection). Pregnant women and men should seek prompt care.

Psoriasis.description: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes rapid buildup of skin cells, resulting in scaling on the skin's surface. The scales are typically whitish-silver and develop in thick, red patches.
symptoms: Red patches of skin covered with silvery scales
Dry, cracked skin that may bleed
causes: Immune system dysfunction (T cells attack healthy skin)
Psoriasis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if psoriasis affects your quality of life, causes joint pain and swelling, or doesn't improve with treatment.

Impetigo.description: Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection that mainly affects infants and children, causing red sores that rupture, ooze, and form a honey-colored crust.
causes: Enter through cuts, insect bites, or skin irritation
Impetigo.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if the rash doesn't improve within 3 days of treatment, spreads rapidly, or is accompanied by fever.

Acne.description: Acne is a skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, causing whiteheads, blackheads, and pimples.
causes: Hair follicles clogged with oil and dead skin
risk_factors: Greasy or oily substances on skin
Acne.when_to_see_doctor: See a dermatologist if over-the-counter products don't help after 2-3 months, acne is severe or causing scars, or acne is affecting your self-esteem.

Arthritis.description: Arthritis is inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age. The most common types are osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
causes: Osteoarthritis: Wear and tear of cartilage
Rheumatoid arthritis: Autoimmune attack on joint lining
Arthritis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you have persistent joint pain, swelling, or stiffness, or if arthritis affects your daily activities.

Vertigo.description: Vertigo is a sensation of spinning dizziness, as though you or your surroundings are moving when they're not. It's often caused by inner ear problems.
Vertigo.when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care for vertigo with severe headache, fever, vision changes, difficulty walking, or fainting. See a doctor if vertigo is recurrent or severe.

Osteoarthritis.description: Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, occurring when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of bones wears down over time.
causes: Wear and tear on joints over time
Osteoarthritis.when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if joint pain and stiffness don't improve, interfere with daily activities, or are accompanied by redness and swelling.
